channel.description: Get advice on getting ahead from The Wall Street Journal. Fuel your ambitions and learn how to make yourself healthy, wealthy and wise.
channel.itunes:author: The Wall Street Journal
channel.itunes:summary: Get advice on getting ahead from The Wall Street Journal. Fuel your ambitions and learn how to make yourself healthy, wealthy and wise.
channel.content:encoded: Get advice on getting ahead from The Wall Street Journal. Fuel your ambitions and learn how to make yourself healthy, wealthy and wise.

item.title: Should Spouses Retire Together?
item.description: Glenn Ruffenach, former editor and reporter for the Wall Street Journal, explores the pros and cons of married couples retiring at the same time. He says that whatever couples decide, they should discuss it beforehand. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit megaphone.fm/adchoices
item.itunes:author: The Wall Street Journal
item.itunes:subtitle: Glenn Ruffenach, former editor and reporter for the Wall Street Journal, explores the pros and cons of married couples retiring at the same time. He says that whatever couples decide, they should discuss it beforehand.
item.itunes:summary: Glenn Ruffenach, former editor and reporter for the Wall Street Journal, explores the pros and cons of married couples retiring at the same time. He says that whatever couples decide, they should discuss it beforehand. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit megaphone.fm/adchoices
item.content:encoded:
Glenn Ruffenach, former editor and reporter for the Wall Street Journal, explores the pros and cons of married couples retiring at the same time. He says that whatever couples decide, they should discuss it beforehand.

Learn more about your ad choices. Visit megaphone.fm/adchoices
item.author: podcast@wsj.com (The Wall Street Journal)

item.title: Mistakes People Make When Paying for College
item.description: As the school year ends, summer vacation offers parents and students alike the opportunity to focus on what may be their most dreaded subject: paying for college. WSJ Contributor Chana Schoenberger takes a closer look. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit megaphone.fm/adchoices
item.itunes:author: The Wall Street Journal
item.itunes:subtitle: As the school year ends, summer vacation offers parents and students alike the opportunity to focus on what may be their most dreaded subject: paying for college. WSJ Contributor Chana Schoenberger takes a closer look.

item.title: Americans Unwilling to Pay to Fight Climate Change
item.description: Americans of all political stripes are worried about climate change. But surveys find they're unwilling to pay what it costs to fight it, according to Wall Street Journal contributor Sam Ori. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit megaphone.fm/adchoices
item.itunes:author: The Wall Street Journal
item.itunes:subtitle: Americans of all political stripes are worried about climate change. But surveys find they're unwilling to pay what it costs to fight it, according to Wall Street Journal contributor Sam Ori.

item.title: Get Ready for Peak Oil Demand
item.description: There's growing consensus that the end of ever-rising oil consumption is in sight. The big question is, when? The Wall Street Journal's Elena Cherney reports from Toronto. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit megaphone.fm/adchoices
item.itunes:author: The Wall Street Journal
item.itunes:subtitle: There's growing consensus that the end of ever-rising oil consumption is in sight. The big question is, when? The Wall Street Journal's Elena Cherney reports from Toronto.

item.title: A Look at the Gas Stations of Tomorrow
item.description: The gas station is in for a major overhaul. The world's big oil companies have all sorts of potential changes on the drawing board, including new fuel options, restaurants, and package-delivery services. WSJ's Sarah Kent reports from London. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit megaphone.fm/adchoices

item.title: Why Are Online Surveys So Bad?
item.description: Wall Street Journal contributor Alexandra Samuel tells us how survey makers could vastly improve surveys. And she does so by creating her own survey, directed at the survey makers. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit megaphone.fm/adchoices

item.title: Some Work Breaks Are More Effective Than Others
item.description: Many of us take breaks at work, but some breaks work better than others at helping us stay effective. Wall Street Journal contributor Heidi Mitchell talks about studies that set out to find which breaks work the best. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit megaphone.fm/adchoices

item.title: Why Getting a Low-Pay Job Out of College is Good
item.description: Derek Tharp says there are benefits to not getting paid a high salary in your first job after college. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit megaphone.fm/adchoices

item.itunes:subtitle: Derek Tharp says there are benefits to not getting paid a high salary in your first job after college.

item.title: How Much Do You Pay in Adviser Fees?
item.description: Wall Street Journal reporter Andrea Fuller had no idea how much she paid in adviser fees for her mutual funds or ETFs. Here's her story of the (beyond) frustrating experience she underwent trying to find out. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit megaphone.fm/adchoices
item.itunes:author: The Wall Street Journal

item.title: The Myth of Entrepreneurial Storytelling
item.description: Stories about how company founders struggled to pursue their dreams and to realize them are quite seductive to would-be entrepreneurs. These tales can also do more harm than good, says Wall Street Journal contributor Morra Aarons-Mele. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit megaphone.fm/adchoices

item.title: What Entrepreneurship Can Teach Us About Life
item.description: Wall Street Journal contributor Stephen Hicks says we all can apply the entrepreneurial approach to our own lives. That's because we're born with the ability to take risks, think creatively and challenge the normal way of doing things. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit megaphone.fm/adchoices

item.title: How Roadside Attractions Try to Make a Profit
item.description: Roadside attractions were spawned from the superhighway systems' creation in the mid-20th century. They're still around, though as Wall Street Journal contributor Kevin Brass says, making money can be tricky. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit megaphone.fm/adchoices

item.title: Investment Professionals Are Really Bad At Telling If People Are Lying
item.description: Our next guest says don't count on investment professionals to sniff out financial fraud. Wall Street Journal Contributor Deborah Gage joins us from San Jose, California and says we can all learn to better tell truth from fiction. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit megaphone.fm/adchoices

item.title: Explaining the Debate Over Financial Regulation
item.description: How to regulate the financial system is crucially important, and often hard to understand. The Wall Street Journal's Andrew Ackerman breaks it down from our newsroom in Washington. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit megaphone.fm/adchoices
item.itunes:author: The Wall Street Journal

item.title: Voluntourism: Tips for Volunteering While Vacationing
item.description: Wall Street Journal Contributor Glenn Ruffenach joins us from Atlanta with a list of tips for mixing vacation time and volunteer work, otherwise known as voluntourism. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit megaphone.fm/adchoices

item.title: When Is Enough... Enough?
item.description: Our next guest says she spent too much of her life chasing more and more. Now, retired, she realizes that enough is often enough. There are lessons for all ages here. Wall Street Journal Contributor Robbie Shell joins us from Philadelphia. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit megaphone.fm/adchoices

item.title: Great Films About Retirement

item.title: Time to Reinvent the Physical Exam
item.description: As much as modern medicine has changed with technology one place you really don't see it is in that annual physical exam. Wall Street Journal Contributor Dr. Peter Pronovost joins us from Johns Hopkins in Baltimore. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit megaphone.fm/adchoices

item.title: Should Patients Record Their Doctors' Visits?
item.description: As phones, tablets and other digital devices become ever more integrated into our daily lives patients are using them to record their trips to the doctor. Wall Street Journal Contributor Dr. Gurpreet Dhaliwal joins us from San Francisco. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit megaphone.fm/adchoices

item.title: Tips for Financing a College Education
item.description: WSJ readers send us a variety of questions about financing college, including how best to use "529" plans, the tax-advantaged higher-education accounts that invest in mutual funds. Contributor Chana Schoenberger helps us go through the mailbag. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit megaphone.fm/adchoices
